Respectfully Translated by Imperial Decree Furthermore, good sons!
If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they will be like the great ocean.
What are the ten?
First, being a great repository of treasures;
Second, being deep and difficult to fathom;
Third, being vast and immeasurable;
Fourth, gradually becoming deeper;
Fifth, not harboring dead bodies;
Sixth, all having the same flavor;
Seventh, accommodating myriad streams;
Eighth, the tides not losing their time;
Ninth, being the support of aquatic life;
Tenth, having no boundaries.
Good sons!
What is meant by bodhisattvas being a great repository of treasures?

It is like the great ocean, which accumulates many treasures, and all the people of Jambudvipa take its treasures without ever exhausting them. Bodhisattvas are also like this, widely accumulating the treasures of omniscience and wisdom, and all sentient beings take these treasures without ever exhausting them. This is the bodhisattvas' great treasure trove.
Moreover, good man!
It is like the great ocean, which is deep and difficult to fathom. Bodhisattvas are also like this, and all sentient beings cannot fathom the extent of the bodhisattvas' Dharma.
Moreover, good man!
It is like the great ocean, which is vast and immeasurable. Bodhisattvas are also like this, with their merits and wisdom vast and immeasurable.
Moreover, good man!
It is like the great ocean, which gradually becomes deeper. Bodhisattvas are also like this, with omniscience being deep, gradually deep, and extremely deep.
Moreover, good man!
It is like the great ocean, which does not retain dead bodies.
Why is it so?
Because the great ocean is naturally like this. Bodhisattvas are also like this, not dwelling together with afflictions, defilements, and unwholesome companions.
Why is it so?
Because bodhisattvas are naturally like this.
Moreover, good man!

Just as the great ocean receives all the rivers and they all become of one taste, namely the salty taste, so it is with bodhisattvas. They accumulate all wholesome dharmas and they all become of one taste, namely the taste of omniscience.
Moreover, good man!

Just as the great ocean can contain all the rivers without the seawater increasing or decreasing, so it is with bodhisattvas. They can contain the waters of all the immeasurable dharmas without the bodhisattvas' wisdom increasing or decreasing.
Moreover, good man!
Just as the great ocean's tides do not lose their time, so it is with bodhisattvas. They mature and liberate sentient beings in accordance with the proper time.
Moreover, good sons!
It is just as the great ocean is the dwelling place for all water creatures. Bodhisattvas are also like this, being the dwelling place for all sentient beings and all wholesome dharmas.
Moreover, good sons!

It is just as the great ocean, no matter how much water all sentient beings take from it, is never depleted. Bodhisattvas are also like this, widely proclaiming the essential teachings for all sentient beings, yet there is no end to them.
Good sons!
If bodhisattvas cultivate these ten kinds of dharmas, they are like the great ocean.
Furthermore, good sons!
If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they attain subtle wisdom.
What are the ten?
First, skillfully seeking liberation;
Second, skillfully knowing all the methods of liberation;
Third, skillfully knowing the equality of all dharmas;
Fourth, skillfully knowing that all dharmas are like illusions;
Fifth, skillfully knowing the characteristics of all dharmas;
Sixth, skillfully understanding the profound and unfathomable principle of dependent origination;
Seventh, skillfully understanding the inconceivability of karma;
Eighth, skillfully understanding the meaning of all that is spoken;ğŸ”½Ninth, skillfully understanding the meaning of suchness as it is;
Tenth, skillfully contemplating the wisdom of true reality.
Good sons!
What is meant by bodhisattvas skillfully seeking liberation, up to skillfully contemplating the wisdom of true reality?
It is said that bodhisattvas should contemplate the characteristics of the world.

They see that in the world, the fire of greed blazes, the smoke of anger billows, and the darkness of delusion covers everything, leaving nothing to rely on. Bodhisattvas then give rise to this thought:
How can these sentient beings attain liberation?
Bodhisattvas then diligently seek liberation and the Dharma of liberation. By attaining the Dharma of liberation, they are able to understand the equality of all dharmas.
By understanding the equality of all dharmas, they are able to know the illusory nature of all dharmas as they are.
Because of knowing that all dharmas are like illusions, one thus truly understands the characteristics of all dharmas.
Because of understanding the characteristics of dharmas, one is then able to contemplate the profound and unfathomable conditioned arising of dharmas.
Because of being able to contemplate the conditioned arising of dharmas, one is then able to understand the inconceivability of karma.

Therefore, although bodhisattvas know that worldly dharmas are unreal, they still reveal various karmic retributions. Because of this, they attain subtle wisdom and are able to fully understand the meanings explained by the buddhas and bodhisattvas. Because of understanding, they are then able to realize the meaning of reality.

Because of understanding the meaning of reality, they are then able to contemplate the wisdom of truth. Because of seeing the truth, they are able to deliver sentient beings and enable them to transcend birth and death.
Good man!
If bodhisattvas cultivate these ten kinds of dharmas, they will attain subtle wisdom.
Furthermore, good man!
If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they will attain appropriate eloquence.
What are the ten?
First, revealing the selflessness of all phenomena;
Second, the absence of sentient beings;
Third, the absence of life;
Fourth, the absence of nurturance;
Fifth, the absence of pudgala;
Sixth, the absence of an agent;
Seventh, the absence of a recipient;
Eighth, the absence of a knower;
Ninth, the absence of a seer;
Tenth, revealing that all phenomena are empty and devoid of a master, all being false and unreal conceptualizations, as phenomena arise only due to conditions.
Good sons!

If one attains the principle of selflessness of all phenomena, one will then accord with the nature of phenomena. For this reason, in all phenomena there are no sentient beings, no life, no nurturance, no pudgala, no agent, no recipient, no knower, no seer, and so forth. Accordance with principle is precisely the ability to accord with the nature of phenomena.

For this reason, one understands that all dharmas are empty and devoid of any master or controller, all being false and unreal discriminations. Dharmas only exist due to arising from conditions. If in accord with principle, one is then able to follow the nature of dharmas.
Good sons!

If one follows the nature of dharmas, then one does not go against the nature of dharmas. Not going against it, one is then able to correctly expound the dharmas. Correctly expounding the dharmas, one well enters the nature of dharmas. Entering the nature of dharmas, one is then able to reveal all those dharmas. Revealing the dharmas, one's eloquence is then called appropriate.
Good sons!
If bodhisattvas cultivate these ten kinds of dharmas, they will attain appropriate eloquence.
Furthermore, good sons!
If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they will attain the eloquence of joyful speech.
What are the ten?
First, eloquence without attachment;
second, inexhaustibility;
third, continuity;
Fourth, they are not afraid of large assemblies;
Fifth, they are not humble;
Sixth, they have no fear;
Seventh, they do not associate with others;
Eighth, they are not arrogant;ğŸ”½Ninth, they are boundless;
Tenth, they have unobstructed eloquence.
Good man!
If bodhisattvas cultivate these ten kinds of dharmas, they will attain the eloquence of joyful speech.
Furthermore, good man!
If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they will attain pure eloquence.
What are the ten?
First, they are not stammering;
Second, their words are not mixed up;
Third, they are far removed from inferiority;
Fourth, their speech is not haughty;
Fifth, their meaning is not diminished;ğŸ”½Sixth, their words are not lacking;
Seventh, their voice is not deficient;
Eighth, they know the right time for everything;
Ninth, their words are not coarse;
Tenth, they are not unclear.
Good sons!
The eloquence of all bodhisattvas is free from stammering.
Why is this?
Because bodhisattvas have no fear in the great assembly.
Moreover, the eloquence of bodhisattvas is free from confusion.
Why is this?
Because the wisdom of bodhisattvas is serene and fearless.
Moreover, the eloquence of bodhisattvas is free from inferiority.
Why is this?
Because bodhisattvas are in the great assembly like lions, free from all fear.
Moreover, the eloquence of bodhisattvas is not arrogant.
Why is this?
Because they are already free from afflictions.
If there are afflictions, speech is arrogant, if not, it is not.
Moreover, the eloquence of bodhisattvas does not diminish in meaning.
Why is this?
Because they have already attained the Dharma.

Moreover, a bodhisattva's eloquence is free from omissions and errors.
Why is this?
Because they have a thorough understanding of all treatises.
If one's understanding of the treatises is scant, then one's eloquence will have omissions and errors, but if one's understanding is thorough, it will not be so.
Moreover, a bodhisattva's eloquence is free from defects in sound.
Why is this?
Because bodhisattvas have a profound understanding of all sounds.
If one does not understand, then one's eloquence will have defects in sound, but if one understands, it will not be so.
Moreover, a bodhisattva's eloquence is always timely, speaking what should be said first without delay, and speaking what should be said later without anticipation.
Why is this?
Because bodhisattvas are well-versed in all times.
Moreover, a bodhisattva's eloquence is free from harshness, is pleasing to the mind, and is delightful to listen to.

Because they have already eliminated faults in speech.ğŸ”½Here is the text with the alignment mistakes fixed and the English translations updated to match the Sanskrit:

Moreover, a bodhisattva's eloquence is always clear and distinct.
Why is this?
Because a bodhisattva's faculties are sharp.
If one's faculties are dull, then one's understanding will not be clear and distinct, if they are sharp, then it will not be so.
Good man!
If a bodhisattva cultivates these ten kinds of dharmas, then he will attain pure eloquence.
Furthermore, good man!
If a bodhisattva cultivates ten kinds of dharmas, he will attain the eloquence that delights all sentient beings.
What are the ten?
First, loving speech;
Second, a smiling face, far from frowning;
Third, speaking in accordance with the meaning;
Fourth, speaking in accordance with the Dharma;
Fifth, impartial speech;
Sixth, not being self-important;
Seventh, not looking down on others;ğŸ”½Eighth, being free from attachment;
Ninth, being free from irritation;
Tenth, they are endowed with various eloquence.
Good sons!
Bodhisattvas can use loving speech to bring joy to all sentient beings.
Moreover, bodhisattvas always manifest a joyful and good appearance, far removed from frowning, bringing joy to all sentient beings.
Moreover, bodhisattvas always speak words that accord with the meaning and are beautiful, bringing joy to all sentient beings.
Moreover, bodhisattvas always speak the Dharma and beneficial words, bringing joy to all sentient beings.
Moreover, bodhisattvas always teach the Dharma equally for sentient beings, bringing joy to all sentient beings.
Moreover, bodhisattvas do not exalt themselves, being far removed from the faults of arrogance and pride, bringing joy to all sentient beings.
Moreover, bodhisattvas do not look down on others, always respectfully teaching the Dharma for sentient beings, bringing joy to all sentient beings.

Moreover, a bodhisattva is free from all defilements and attachments, and possesses pure precepts, causing all sentient beings to give rise to joy.ğŸ”½ Moreover, a bodhisattva is free from all vexations and possesses much forbearance, causing all sentient beings to give rise to joy.
Moreover, a bodhisattva possesses various kinds of eloquence and always speaks pleasing words, causing all sentient beings to give rise to joy.
Good man!
If a bodhisattva cultivates these ten kinds of dharmas, he will attain the eloquence that delights all sentient beings.
Furthermore, good man!
If a bodhisattva cultivates ten kinds of dharmas, he will attain the Dharma of faithful acceptance and explanation.
What are the ten?
First, a bodhisattva does not expound the Dharma for sentient beings who are not vessels of the Dharma;
Second, he does not expound the Dharma for those who have obstacles;
Third, he does not expound the Dharma for those who have the view of attainment;
Fourth, he does not expound the Dharma for those of wrong, heterodox paths;
Fifth, do not expound the Dharma to those who do not give rise to a desirous mind;
Sixth, do not expound the Dharma to those who do not give rise to a pure mind;
Seventh, do not expound the Dharma to those with deceitful minds;
Eighth, do not expound the Dharma to those seeking a livelihood;
Ninth, do not expound the Dharma to those who are attached to gain and offerings and are bound by stinginess and jealousy;
Tenth, do not expound the Dharma to the blind, deaf, and mute.
Why is it so?
Good man!
Bodhisattvas do not hoard the Dharma or keep it secret. They have compassion for all sentient beings and do not abandon them for the sake of benefiting sentient beings.
Why is it so?
If there are sentient beings who are not suitable vessels, bodhisattvas will think like this:
'These sentient beings will give up practicing the TathÄgata's teachings.'
Bodhisattva Sarva-RÅ«pa-Kauká¹›tya-VinodanÄ« addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
If so, for what kind of sentient beings should the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas expound the Dharma?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
For sentient beings endowed with faith, the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas should expound the Dharma.

Moreover, if the roots of goodness have already matured, if they are vessels of the Dharma, if they have planted various roots of virtue under past Buddhas, if they are without flattery or deception, if they do not falsely display dignified deportment, if they are not attached to material gain, if their profound mind is complete, if they are embraced by good and virtuous friends, if they are endowed with good characteristics and are delightful to behold, if their faculties are sharp and they understand the meaning of the teachings they hear, if they diligently practice the teachings they receive, if they are able to practice in accordance with the Buddha's teachings, for such sentient beings the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas will expound the Dharma.
Good man!
If Bodhisattvas cultivate these ten kinds of dharmas, they will then be able to expound the Dharma in accordance with faith.
Furthermore, good man!
If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they become Dharma teachers.
What are the ten?
First, in order to cultivate the Buddha Dharma, they expound the Dharma, but do not see any Buddha Dharma that can be attained, nor do they see anything to be cultivated;
Second, in order to cultivate the perfections, they expound the Dharma, but do not see any perfections that can be attained, nor do they see anything to be cultivated;

Third, in order to cultivate the bodhisattva Dharma, they expound the Dharma, but do not see any bodhisattva Dharma that can be attained, nor do they see anything to be cultivated;ğŸ”½Fourth, in order to eliminate afflictions, they expound the Dharma, but do not see any afflictions that can be attained, nor do they see any elimination;
Fifth, in order to expound the Dharma of disgust, detachment, and cessation, they do not see any disgust, detachment, or cessation that can be attained;

Sixth, he preaches the Dharma in order to attain the fruits of stream-entry, once-returning, and non-returning, but does not see any stream-enterer, once-returner, or non-returner to be attained, nor does he see any fruit;ğŸ”½Seventh, he preaches the Dharma in order to attain the fruit of arhatship, but does not see any arhat to be attained, nor does he see any fruit;
Eighth, he preaches the Dharma in order to attain the fruit of pratyekabuddhahood, but does not see any pratyekabuddha to be attained, nor does he see any fruit;
Ninth, he preaches the Dharma in order to sever attachment to the notion of self, but does not see any self to be attained, nor does he see any attachment;
Tenth, he preaches the Dharma in order to reveal karmic retribution, but does not see any karma to be attained, nor does he see any retribution.
Why is it so?
All such dharmas are devoid of real substance, but are proclaimed by means of provisional names, and even the names do not exist.
Why is it so?
Because the nature of words is empty, and phenomena are free from words. It is only through worldly conventions that names are established for that which is nameless.
Because those names are empty, they are originally false. In the ultimate truth, there are no false names.
Because there are no false names, there are no false phenomena in the ultimate truth.
Those false phenomena deceive foolish people.
Good man!
If bodhisattvas cultivate these ten kinds of dharmas, they will become Dharma teachers.
Furthermore, good man!
If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they can contemplate the nature of dharmas in accordance with reality.
What are the ten?

First, although bodhisattvas contemplate the nature of dharmas in accordance with reality, they do not destroy the characteristics of form; although they contemplate the nature of dharmas in accordance with reality, they do not destroy the characteristics of feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness;
Second, although they contemplate the nature of dharmas in accordance with reality, they do not destroy the characteristics of the desire realm;
Third, although they contemplate the nature of dharmas in accordance with reality, they do not destroy the characteristics of the form realm;
Fourth, although contemplating in accordance with the nature of dharmas, not destroying the characteristics of the formless realm;
Fifth, although contemplating in accordance with the nature of dharmas, not destroying the characteristics of all dharmas;
Sixth, although contemplating in accordance with the nature of dharmas, not seeing the characteristics of conformity of all dharmas;
Seventh, although contemplating in accordance with the nature of dharmas, not seeing the characteristics of sentient beings;
Eighth, although contemplating in accordance with the nature of dharmas, not falling into the view of annihilation;
Ninth, although contemplating in accordance with the nature of dharmas, not losing the right path;
Tenth, although contemplating in accordance with the nature of dharmas, not apart from the skillful means of wisdom.
Good man!
If bodhisattvas cultivate these ten kinds of dharmas, they will be able to contemplate in accordance with the nature of dharmas.
Furthermore, good man!
If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they will be skilled in understanding the principle of the dharma realm.
What are the ten?
First, having wisdom;
Second, being accepted by good and virtuous friends;
Third, giving rise to diligence;
Fourth, being free from all afflictive hindrances;
Fifth, skillfully cultivating pure practices;
Sixth, respecting and praising the Dharma;
Seventh, skillfully cultivating the contemplation of emptiness;
Eighth, being free from the view of attaining something;
Ninth, heading towards the right path;
Tenth, seeing the true reality of dharmas.
Good man!
Because the bodhisattva is endowed with wisdom, he is able to diligently seek out good and wise advisors.
Having seen the good and wise advisors, his mind gives rise to joy, thinking of them as teachers and superiors, and he draws near to them and relies on them.

Because he is able to rely on the good and wise advisors, he gives rise to diligence, cuts off all unwholesome dharmas, and perfects all pure and wholesome dharmas. He diligently practices and is free from all afflictive hindrances. Because he is free from the afflictive hindrances, he attains lightness and ease. He skillfully cultivates pure practices and is free from all faults of body, speech, and mind.

Because of purity, one respects and praises the attained Dharma. Because of respecting the Dharma, one cultivates the view of emptiness extensively. Because of cultivating the view of emptiness, one does not give rise to the view of attainment. Because of being free from the view of attainment, one practices in accordance with the right path. Because of entering the right path, one is able to contemplate reality.

What is called true suchness?
The Buddha said:
Good sons!
This Dharma is only realized internally, it cannot be expressed through written words or language.
Why is this?

Because this Dharma transcends all written words, it is beyond all speech, it transcends all realms of language, it is beyond the path of words, free from all idle discourse, free from action and non-action, without movement or stillness, free from all speculation, it is the realm of the inconceivable.

It is without characteristics, not without characteristics, and completely free from all characterized realms, transcending all ordinary realms, surpassing the practices of ordinary beings, going beyond all demonic realms, and transcending all realms of afflictions.

Free from all realms of consciousness, it peacefully abides in the supreme and tranquil realm of holy wisdom, which is without abode. Therefore, this Dharma is only realized internally. It is then the Dharma that is without defilement, without stain, pure and clean, the most supreme, the most excellent, the unsurpassed, the eternally abiding, the firmly established, the ultimately indestructible Dharma. Whether the TathÄgata appears in the world or not, this Dharma always abides.
Good sons!

Bodhisattvas, in seeking this Dharma, undergo hundreds of thousands of difficult and painful practices, and thus attain this Dharma. Having attained this Dharma, they cause all sentient beings to abide in this Dharma.
Good sons!ğŸ”½Therefore, this Dharma is called true suchness, the ultimate reality, the knowledge of all things, the knowledge of all modes, the inconceivable realm, and the non-dual realm.
